ruleset.name: Basic
ruleset.description: The Basic ruleset contains a collection of good practices which should be followed.

rule.name: JumbledIncrementer
rule.message: Avoid modifying an outer loop incrementer in an inner loop for update expression
rule.description: Avoid jumbled loop incrementers - its usually a mistake, and is confusing even if intentional.

rule.name: ForLoopShouldBeWhileLoop
rule.message: This for loop could be simplified to a while loop
rule.description: Some for loops can be simplified to while loops, this makes them more concise.

rule.name: OverrideBothEqualsAndHashcode
rule.message: Ensure you override both equals() and hashCode()
rule.description: Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode() from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

rule.name: DoubleCheckedLocking
rule.message: Double checked locking is not thread safe in Java.
rule.description:
Partially created objects can be returned by the Double Checked Locking pattern when used in Java. An optimizing JRE may assign a reference to the baz variable before it calls the constructor of the object the reference points to.
Note: With Java 5, you can make Double checked locking work, if you declare the variable to be `volatile`.
For more details refer to: <http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2001/jw-0209-double.html> or <http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/DoubleCheckedLocking.html>

rule.name: ReturnFromFinallyBlock
rule.message: Avoid returning from a finally block
rule.description: Avoid returning from a finally block, this can discard exceptions.

rule.name: UnconditionalIfStatement
rule.message: Do not use 'if' statements that are always true or always false
rule.description: Do not use "if" statements whose conditionals are always true or always false.

rule.name: BooleanInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; reference Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.
rule.description: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; you can reference Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE, or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.
rule.example: Boolean bar = new Boolean("true"); // unnecessary creation, just reference Boolean.TRUE; Boolean buz = Boolean.valueOf(false); // ...., just reference Boolean.FALSE;

rule.name: CollapsibleIfStatements
rule.message: These nested if statements could be combined
rule.description: Sometimes two consecutive 'if' statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator.

rule.name: ClassCastExceptionWithToArray
rule.message: This usage of the Collection.toArray() method will throw a ClassCastException.
rule.description: When deriving an array of a specific class from your Collection, one should provide an array of the same class as the parameter of the toArray() method. Doing otherwise you will will result in a ClassCastException.

rule.name: AvoidDecimalLiteralsInBigDecimalConstructor
rule.message: Avoid creating BigDecimal with a decimal (float/double) literal. Use a String literal
rule.description:
One might assume that the result of "new BigDecimal(0.1)" is exactly equal to 0.1, but it is actually equal to .1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is because 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double (or as a binary fraction of any finite length). Thus, the long value that is being passed in to the constructor is not exactly equal to 0.1, appearances notwithstanding.
The (String) constructor, on the other hand, is perfectly predictable: 'new BigDecimal("0.1")' is exactly equal to 0.1, as one would expect. Therefore, it is generally recommended that the (String) constructor be used in preference to this one.

property.name: xpath
property.value: //AllocationExpression [ClassOrInterfaceType[@Image="BigDecimal"]] [Arguments/ArgumentList/Expression/PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix [ Literal[(not(ends-with(@Image,'"'))) and contains(@Image,".")] or Name[ancestor::Block/BlockStatement/LocalVariableDeclaration [Type[PrimitiveType[@Image='double' or @Image='float'] or ReferenceType/ClassOrInterfaceType[@Image='Double' or @Image='Float']]] /VariableDeclarator/VariableDeclaratorId/@Image = @Image ] or Name[ancestor::MethodDeclaration/MethodDeclarator/FormalParameters/FormalParameter [Type[PrimitiveType[@Image='double' or @Image='float'] or ReferenceType/ClassOrInterfaceType[@Image='Double' or @Image='Float']]] /VariableDeclaratorId/@Image = @Image ] ] ]

rule.example:
BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(1.123); // loss of precision, this would trigger the rule
BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal("1.123"); // preferred approach
BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(12); // preferred approach, ok for integer values

rule.name: MisplacedNullCheck
rule.message: The null check here is misplaced; if the variable is null there will be a NullPointerException
rule.description: The null check here is misplaced. If the variable is null a NullPointerException will be thrown. Either the check is useless (the variable will never be "null") or it is incorrect.

rule.name: AvoidThreadGroup
rule.message: Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; it is not thread safe
rule.description: Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; although it is intended to be used in a threaded environment it contains methods that are not thread-safe.

rule.name: BrokenNullCheck
rule.message: Method call on object which may be null
rule.description: The null check is broken since it will throw a NullPointerException itself. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.

rule.name: BigIntegerInstantiation
rule.message: Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger and BigDecimal (ZERO, ONE, TEN)
rule.description: Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger (BigInteger.ZERO, BigInteger.ONE) and for Java 1.5 onwards, BigInteger.TEN and BigDecimal (BigDecimal.ZERO, BigDecimal.ONE, BigDecimal.TEN)
rule.example: BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(1); // reference BigInteger.ONE instead BigInteger bi2 = new BigInteger("0"); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead BigInteger bi3 = new BigInteger(0.0); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead BigInteger bi4; bi4 = new BigInteger(0); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

rule.name: AvoidUsingOctalValues
rule.message: Do not start a literal by 0 unless it's an octal value
rule.description: Integer literals should not start with zero since this denotes that the rest of literal will be interpreted as an octal value.
rule.example: int i = 012; // set i with 10 not 12 int j = 010; // set j with 8 not 10 k = i * j; // set k with 80 not 120

rule.name: AvoidUsingHardCodedIP
rule.message: Do not hard code the IP address ${variableName}
rule.description: Application with hard-coded IP addresses can become impossible to deploy in some cases. Externalizing IP adresses is preferable.

rule.name: CheckResultSet
rule.message: Always check the return of one of the navigation method (next,previous,first,last) of a ResultSet.
rule.description: Always check the return values of navigation methods (next, previous, first, last) of a ResultSet. If the value return is 'false', it should be handled properly.

rule.name: AvoidMultipleUnaryOperators
rule.message: Using multiple unary operators may be a bug, and/or is confusing.
rule.description: The use of multiple unary operators may be problematic, and/or confusing. Ensure that the intended usage is not a bug, or consider simplifying the expression.

rule.name: ExtendsObject
rule.message: No need to explicitly extend Object.
rule.description: No need to explicitly extend Object.
rule.example: public class Foo extends Object { // not required }

rule.name: CheckSkipResult
rule.message: Check the value returned by the skip() method of an InputStream to see if the requested number of bytes has been skipped.
rule.description: The skip() method may skip a smaller number of bytes than requested. Check the returned value to find out if it was the case or not.

rule.name: AvoidBranchingStatementAsLastInLoop
rule.message: Avoid using a branching statement as the last in a loop.
rule.description: Using a branching statement as the last part of a loop may be a bug, and/or is confusing. Ensure that the usage is not a bug, or consider using another approach.

rule.name: DontCallThreadRun
rule.message: Don't call Thread.run() explicitly, use Thread.start()
rule.description: Explicitly calling Thread.run() method will execute in the caller's thread of control. Instead, call Thread.start() for the intended behavior.

property.name: xpath
property.value: //StatementExpression/PrimaryExpression [ PrimaryPrefix [ ./Name[ends-with(@Image, '.run') or @Image = 'run'] and substring-before(Name/@Image, '.') =//VariableDeclarator/VariableDeclaratorId/@Image [../../../Type/ReferenceType[ClassOrInterfaceType/@Image = 'Thread']] or ( ./AllocationExpression/ClassOrInterfaceType[@Image = 'Thread'] and ../PrimarySuffix[@Image = 'run']) ] ]

rule.name: DontUseFloatTypeForLoopIndices
rule.message: Don't use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double.
rule.description: Don't use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double unless you're certain that float provides enough precision and you have a compelling performance need (space or time).

rule.name: SimplifiedTernary
rule.message: Ternary operators that can be simplified with || or &&
rule.description:
Look for ternary operators with the form `condition ? literalBoolean : foo` or `condition ? foo : literalBoolean`.
These expressions can be simplified respectively to `condition || foo` when the literalBoolean is true `!condition && foo` when the literalBoolean is false or `!condition || foo` when the literalBoolean is true `condition && foo` when the literalBoolean is false
